STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER
LANS ING
ELIZABETH HERTEL
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
January 20, 2023
Carey Jo Adrianse
WEXFORD/MISSAUKEE COUNTY DHHS
10641 W WATERGATE RD
CADILLAC, MI 49601-9424
RE: License #: CP830201508
10641 W WATERGATE RD
CADILLAC, MI 49601-9424
Dear Carey Jo Adrianse:
Attached is the Interim Report for the above referenced facility completed on November 21,
2022. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, sections of the contract and
MISEP requirements, a written corrective action plan is required. It should be noted that
violations of any licensing rules are also violations of the MISEP and your contract. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
licensing statute and rule or section of the contract or MISEP citation.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
P.O. BOX 30650 • LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov • (517) 335-1980

Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact Kari Muntean, Area Manager, at 734-395-0920.
Sincerely,
Douglas W Turrill, Licensing Consultant
enclosure
2

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules.
2.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also an MISEP violation. Please note that
there are additional MISEP requirements that may not be included in section 1.
The facility is in compliance will all additional MISEP requirements.
3.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also a MDHHS Contract violation. Please
note that there are additional MDHHS Contract/Policy requirements that may not
be included in section 1. The facility is in compliance will all additional MDHHS
Contract/Policy requirements except for the following:
FOM 06H Case Contacts – Timely Entry
The caseworker must enter the required face-to-face
contacts listed below in the electronic case
management record within five business days of the
contact. This includes attempted and missed face-to-
face contacts. • Any face-to-face contact with
children, parents, or caregivers made by any of the
following: Foster care caseworker or supervisor.
Child protective services (CPS) caseworker or
supervisor. Adoption caseworker or supervisor.
Permanency resource monitors. Michigan Youth
Opportunities Initiative (MYOI) coordinators. • Parent-
child face-to-face contacts. • Sibling face-to-face
contacts.
Six foster care files were reviewed. Three of six files contained face to face contacts
that were entered late, beyond the five business days as required by the policy.
FOM 722-06B Family Team Meeting
The DHS-1105, Family Team Meeting Report, is used
to capture family demographics, FTM logistical
information, needs, strengths, action steps, safety
concerns and the safety plan, and any
recommendations made for the family during the
FTM. The DHS-1105, Family Team Meeting Report,
must be completed for every FTM.
The caseworker must enter the FTM information in the
electronic case management record using the FTM
hyperlink within seven business days of the FTM.
3

Six files and twenty FTM’s were reviewed. Two of six files did not have the DHHS-1105
uploaded or the DHHS-1105 was not completed. One file did not have DHHS-1105
uploaded for an FTM that occurred on October 19, 2022. A second file did not have the
DHHS-1105 uploaded for FTM’s that occurred on February 23, 2022, May 5, 2022, July
15, 2022, and October 26, 2022. A third did not document that the DHHS-1105 form was
completed for FTM’s that occurred on March 29, 2022, and October 4, 2022.
FOM 722-08D Treatment Plans - PATP
Once completed and approved, the caseworker must
obtain signatures from the following individuals, as
applicable.
• Caseworker. • Supervisor. • Second line supervisor,
when siblings in care are placed apart. • Parents who
are a member of a participating household. • Youth
ages 14 and older. • Foster parents, relative
caregivers, and unrelated court ordered caregivers.
Six files and 20 PATP’s were reviewed. Four of six files contained one or more PATP’s
that lacked signatures or signatures were late. One file contained a PATP dated May 9,
2022, that lacked signatures. The same file contained a PATP dated February 11, 2022,
that documented late parental signatures. The parent signatures were dated April 20,
2022, and March 22, 2022. The foster parent also signed the plan late on March 29,
2022. A second file contained a PATP dated October 4, 2022, that lacked signatures.
This same file contained a PATP dated July 6, 2022, that lacked signatures. A third file
did not have signatures on a October 13, 2022, PATP which was also not uploaded. A
fourth file contained a PATP dated June 25, 2022, that was signed late by the parent on
August 30, 2022.
FOM 801-03 Medical Passport
All medical information within the medical passport
must be current and updated at least quarterly to
reflect the child's current and complete health
information.
Six files and 17 medical passports were reviewed. Two of six files reviewed were
missing updated passports. One file did not contain any passports since June 2, 2022.
A second file did not contain any passports since March 30, 2022.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
Technical assistance was provided regarding youth with YAVFC status who are
placed in an independent living placement. Discussion involved YAVFC youth, when
4

living in an independent living arrangement such as a college dorm or an apartment,
the youth is then considered to be in independent living and therefore independent
living rules apply. The independent living rules do not apply to YAVFC youth living
with a relative, in a foster home, or in a CCI.
V. CONSULTATION
Consultation was not requested or offered at this time.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this
licensing period. - Pulled from Incident of Maltreatment on Evaluation of
Renewal Period.
The agency has submitted 1 acceptable corrective action plan not related to
maltreatment during this licensing period.
The agency submitted one corrective action plan during the licensing period. The
corrective action plan was approved on September 29, 2021, in response to those
violations established during the Renewal inspection completed September 15,
2021. The current Interim Inspection did not establish any repeat rule or policy
violations indicating that the agency corrective action plan was sucessful in
preventing repeat violations.
Chief Administrators Annual Assessment:
The Chief Administrators Assessment: The assessment identified areas of policy
non-compliance during the year however these were mostly due to systemic
problems beyond the control of the agency. For example, in one case the presiding
Judge did not allow sibling visits out of concern for one or more of the childrens
safety. In addition some parent visitations were not occuring due to the non-
paticipatory parent. Concerns with illness also required virtual visitation in some
circumstances.
Staff Inteviews:
Staff interviewed reported they liked working for the agency as they feel supported
by their supervisors and they feel they are part of a supportive team. Supervisors
reported feeling they have quality workers and a solid, supportive team at the
agency.
VII. FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
The Field Analyst identified four safety alerts during her visits to the agency homes.
They are listed as follows;
5

Safety Alert #1. One home did not have a carbon monoxide alarm detector as well
as no smoke alarm in the basement. A safety alert was generated on August 30,
2022, and resolution was obtained on September 8, 2022. Photos of the newly
installed alarms were provided by the agency.
Safety Alert #2. A safety alert was generated on September 2, 2022, as the home
did not have a carbon monoxide detector and resolution was obtained on September
6, 2022. A photo was provided by the agency of the installed detector.
Safety Alert #3. A safety alert was generated on August 30, 2022, as the home had
firearms that were not properly stored, lacking trigger locks. The agency initiated a
special evaluation. Resolution was achieved on August 31, 2022. The agency
provided photos of the trigger locked firearms.
Safety Alert #4. A safety alert was generated on August 22, 2022, as an adult son
of the family, previously unidentified, was living on the property. An addendum to the
license was completed as well as clearances. Resolution was achieved on
September 9, 2022.
During the entrance conference on November 7, 2022, the Field Analyst reported
that foster parents and relatives reported being satisfied with services the agency
was providing and they felt supported by agency staff. No major concerns were
reported to the Field Analyst by the foster parents and relatives.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules and/or MISEP requirements and/or contract/policy. Upon
receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it is recommended that the facility
continue on a regular license.
January 3, 2023
______________________________________
Douglas W Turrill Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
January 20, 2023
